r3419 | sdonfack | 2013-09-12 14:27:25 -0400 (Thu, 12 Sep 2013) | 4 lines
Changed paths:
   A /trunk/exp_magma_quark

exp_magma_quark is a temporary name. We are still looking for a better name, so if you have a better suggestion, just let us know.
This director will contains a new hybrid scheduling strategies between CPU and GPU. By defaut, it uses quark but any others scheduling can be adapted easily.
More info, check the README file.

update nb=32 version zhemv; using a little more shared memory to enable sort of pipelining.
see a few Gflops increase in performance

------------------------------------------------------------------------
r1811 | tdong | 2012-04-24 19:09:25 -0400 (Tue, 24 Apr 2012) | 14 lines
Changed paths:
   M /trunk/magmablas/zhemv_fermi.cu


modify zhemv_fermi.cu and chemv_fermi.cu, 
Add an algorithm with the blocks size=32 with 10% performance enhancement compared to old algorithm blocksize =64.
The drawback is therefore, it requires double workspace. 
So, the dafault setting is using block size 64;
If you want to use blocksize = 32 code in your higher level kernels, do the following:
1) turn on the macro NB_64 in zhemv_fermi.cu
2) make sure your workspace is allocated properly;


m, and those below, will be ignored--

M    zhemv_fermi.cu

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Add ReleaseNotes file
------------------------------------------------------------------------
r1014 | mfaverge | 2011-04-06 17:24:32 -0400 (Wed, 06 Apr 2011) | 21 lines
Changed paths:
   D /branches/sc_release
   A /trunk (from /branches/sc_release:1013)

Move the sc_release as trunk.
Be carefull, it will causes trouble since the release has not been created from a copy of the previous trunk. The fact that I moved around all the directory may cause troubles.

If you didn't have any changes in the sc_release AND in the trunk directory:
   - just go in the root directory of magma svn and do a first svn update to revision 1013 "svn up -r 1013" to remove the old trunk directory. Then do a second update to the last version to get the last version of the directory.

If you have changes in the trunk directory, do a backup in another directory, you can still see the difference with the svn by doing:
        "svn switch https://icl.cs.utk.edu/svn/magma/attic/trunk ." in your copy.

It's the same with the sc_release directory:
        - First do a backup outside the svn.
        - Update the root directory to the release 1013
        - Update to the last release
        - Apply the switch to your bacckup directory "svn switch https://icl.cs.utk.edu/svn/magma/trunk ." inside your old version.
        - Update it to the last revision number and you can now move it to replace the trunk. This way you will keep your changes.

Mathieu

r900 | du | 2011-02-17 01:47:46 -0500 (Thu, 17 Feb 2011) | 29 lines

   M /branches/sc_release/magmablas/strsm_tesla.cu

fixed the bug with 

./testing_dgetrf_gpu -M 287 -N 579

used to be:

[tomov@cumin testing]$ ./testing_dgetrf_gpu -M 287 -N 579                 
device 0: GeForce GTX 280, 1296.0 MHz clock, 1023.8 MB memory
device 1: Quadro NVS 290, 918.0 MHz clock, 255.3 MB memory
testing_dgetrf -M 287 -N 579
M     N   CPU GFlop/s    GPU GFlop/s   ||PA-LU||/(||A||*N)
============================================================
287   579    1.91         4418.97         3.925370e-04

now is:

du:disco ~/disco-home/sandbox/clean-svn/run/testing> ./testing_dgetrf_gpu -M 287 -N 579
device 0: Tesla C2050, 1147.0 MHz clock, 3071.7 MB memory
device 1: Quadro NVS 290, 918.0 MHz clock, 255.7 MB memory
testing_dgetrf -M 287 -N 579
M     N   CPU GFlop/s    GPU GFlop/s   ||PA-LU||/(||A||*N)
============================================================
287   579    2.63           6.77         4.699152e-18

Problem is caused by unnecessary loop in the inverse kernel when the triangular matrix size is smaller than NB. 

This fix is for the upper case. looking into the lower case now.

r824 | tomov | 2011-01-12 17:27:54 -0500 (Wed, 12 Jan 2011) | 20 lines
Changed paths:
   M /branches/sc_release/testing/Makefile
   M /branches/sc_release/testing/testing_zgetrf_gpu_f.f

This fixes the fortran example. Now this works in all precisions and 
uses the magma module.

A few issues here:
* in the new FORTRAN interface to magma, how are the arrays to the data passed?
* I used for example 'integer pntrA(4)' - this is inportant because the users
  would be required to do it; we have also to include it in the module
  - this doesn't look natural though; is there something else in fortran
    that can be used; 
  - just integer did not work; less than 4 did not work for all precision;
    we use it just for something like a pointer, so I assume we just have to
    give a big enough number so that the interfaces do not overwrite it???
  - can we use some automatic generation for the different precisions?
    maybe we have to have 4 modules for the different precisions and one
    magma module that contains the 4 precision modules?

The module generation for now is in testing but after finalizing it we 
have to put magma.mod in include

This is a dirty fix. Some possible issues that may have to be addressed:
 - Before Quark and additional threads were created every time; 
 - Now Quark threads are created only once;
 - Before additional threads were created and after that Quark threads
 - Now Quark threads are created at the beginning and for every test 
   additional threads; is this an issue for the performance (I remember
   the order was important in one case)
 - Additional magma threads may have to be created only once
 - We need performance results for this routine (and to make sure
   nothing is broken with these latest changes).

r778 | tomov | 2010-12-22 22:05:00 -0500 (Wed, 22 Dec 2010) | 14 lines
Changed paths:
   M /branches/sc_release/include/magma.h
   M /branches/sc_release/include/magma_z.h
   M /branches/sc_release/src/Makefile
   M /branches/sc_release/src/zgetrf_mc.cpp
   M /branches/sc_release/testing/testing_zgetrf_mc.cpp

Mitch, probably we want QR and Cholesky to look like this, 
done for the case of LU.

The changes include:
1) Added magma_init
2) magma_init returns magma hardware context that would be used in 
   consequent computations
3) if (num_cpus == 1 && num_gpus == 1) we call the current magma 1.0
   if (num_gpus == 0) we call th multicore code
   if (num_gpus > 1) we print not supported yet and set num_gpus to 1.
   if (num_gpus > 1 && num_gpus == 1) call the experimental code
     - for now done for QR.

r753 | tomov | 2010-12-20 18:10:45 -0500 (Mon, 20 Dec 2010) | 7 lines
Changed paths:
   M /branches/sc_release/include/magma_z.h
   M /branches/sc_release/make.inc.ig
   A /branches/sc_release/src/zungqr.cpp
   M /branches/sc_release/src/zungqr_gpu.cpp
   M /branches/sc_release/testing/testing_zungqr_gpu.cpp

Added is one more argument to zungqr, namely nb. This is needed because
zungqr is called from several routines, not just after zgeqrf, so the matrices T
that are used in it can have different sizes (depending on the algorithm called before, 
e.g, QR, Hessenberg, bidiagonalizations, etc.).
Also added file zungqr.cpp which will be the CPU version of zungqr. Still have to 
modify it to do what is supposed to.

r741 | tomov | 2010-12-20 11:32:54 -0500 (Mon, 20 Dec 2010) | 12 lines

Here is the zlat2c. I don't see why there was a need for such complicated transfer.
Rajib, if you read, why did we need all that shared memory allocation?
I removed it as single precision is allocated anyway and we don't have to be
carefull not to overwrite the lower, correspondingly upper, parts of the matrix,
as this is just a working copy.

About the bug. I see I added defintion of cublasDsymv on tesla - apparantly
is missing. This makes me remember that our difference with complex is that
in complex we use CUBLAS, i.e., it could be a problem in magmablas_dsymv.
Tim, I hope you have checked these for any sides, not just multiple of the
block size. Somebody has to check if the error comes from the use of magmablas.

r563 | tomov | 2010-12-05 18:04:34 -0500 (Sun, 05 Dec 2010) | 5 lines
Changed paths:
   M /branches/sc_release/testing/results_fermi.txt

Update the single precision performance of sorgqr. Again, this is significantly higher.
In general, all our CPU codes should use the blocking versions because our 'ib's are
significantly bigger than the ib for non-blocking code. This is also true for the
tiled codes - we have to make sure everything is blocking even when we use a single thread.

This is a fix to a potential bug.

There is no page protection in GPU memory.
So it doesn't matter where pointer is.
It will work as long you don't overwrite some other data.

List status of files in src directory. It would nice if everyone could concentrate on cleaning all these files before to add any other files, that we will probably have to clean too or before to work on magmablas.
So please:
   - stop adding new files in the svn, except missing testings
   - If you add files, add working, commented and clean files. We shouldn't have to touch again an additional file. 
   - Use the option -Wall when you compile and remove the warning from your code
   - Use cuDoubleComplex and cuFloatComplex instead of float2 and double2
   - Try to follow as much as possible the lapack interface
   - If possible move to C code instead of F2C with meaningfull variable instead of i_1, i_2, i_3, ...
Thanks to everybody to follow this.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
r514 | tomov | 2010-11-30 21:30:46 -0500 (Tue, 30 Nov 2010) | 12 lines
Changed paths:
   M /branches/sc_release/src/zlabrd.cpp

Piotr, thanks, this seems to work now.
I am still not sure why it works though. In particular, there is at the 
beggining of labrd offset for dy that we make it twice. Clearly the first 
one was meant for dx. I didn't fix it now because it can also brake the 
code before we understand why is working now (but I put it in comment
for possible change in future).
Also I added (again in comment) a possible optimization - the second
gemv on the GPU has a vector with stride lda. This usually kills the
performance (at least this was the case on tesla). I added in comments
where we first copy the vector in a contiguous vector and than do
the matrix-vector product.

r480 | luszczek | 2010-11-26 09:26:48 -0500 (Fri, 26 Nov 2010) | 11 lines
Changed paths:
   M /branches/sc_release/src/zlabrd.cpp

This version of zlabrd.cpp comes from revision 348 with some minor tweaks to make it compile.
This version works for single and double precision real. Both complex versions are still broken.
And this is despite of all the conjugation calls inserted (ZLACG) and all Transposes converted
to Conjugate transposes.

I've tried a number of things over the last few days. I still don't know that is wrong.
The only reason why I'm checking it in so that we have something that works better that
revision 370. Ideally, we'd like the revision 370 (because it's clean) and that works.
I'm not there yet.

r479 | tomov | 2010-11-26 02:27:07 -0500 (Fri, 26 Nov 2010) | 6 lines

   M /branches/sc_release/src/slabrd-v2.cpp

An optimization added.
Added is also how we call the magma blas. This is not convenient
for automatic switching later. The interface of the current gemv
has to be extended as in BLAS and inside call our code if the case 
is as now or CUBLAS for a general case.

the algorithm is different from fermi version. and its performance not so good as fermi version because, it use 
a simple methods. just a little bit higher than cublas which is 2.44Gflps, zhemv is 3.77Gflops. 
This maybe serve as release temporarily, but wait for optimizatio aftwards.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
r343 | tomov | 2010-11-13 22:10:36 -0500 (Sat, 13 Nov 2010) | 19 lines
Changed paths:
   M /branches/sc_release/magmablas/dgemm_fermi.cu
   M /branches/sc_release/magmablas/strsm_tesla.cu

Some fixes in the magma gemms. These have to be tested, especially the dgemm
because I removed something that Pend had and there may be possibilities for
some type of segmentation faults on the GPU. I haven't seen problems so far.
Performance is very good and uniform. Peng, good job in generalizing the gemms.
 
Peng, in what cases did you see problems if we remove "(bll<k)*"?
I forgot if I already asked this. I tested without it and everything works, 
directl testing and through LU.

If there are no problems removing it I may take it out from sgemm.
We loose performance with it when everything is divisible (about 10GFlop/s in
double and 20 in single). Otherwise we have to provide a second implementation
for nice dimensions.

By the way, does anybody know what is the size of a matrix that we can bind
to a texture in Fermi? NVIDIA people are doing some test on this. I tested for
large problems without checking and didn't see a problem. Is this possible to
be an issues only for the cards with 6GB.

r258 | tomov | 2010-10-31 15:09:59 -0400 (Sun, 31 Oct 2010) | 55 lines
Changed paths:
   A /branches/sc_release/testing/fortran2.cpp
   A /branches/sc_release/testing/getrf_f.f

I figured our how to call magma from fortran but now everything is a mess.
I can not figure out how to fix the genrators ... in testing.
These two files work in single precision. I compile them with

gcc -g3 -I/usr/local/cuda-2.3/src/ -I/usr/local/cuda-2.3/include -c fortran2.cpp -o fortran2.o        

gfortran -fPIC getrf_f.o -o getrf_f lin/liblapacktest.a -L../lib -lcuda -lmagma -lmagmablas -L/home/tomov/intel/mkl/10.0.1.014/lib/em64t -L/usr/local/cuda-2.3/lib64 -lmkl_em64t -lguide -lpthread -lcublas -lcudart -lm get_nb.cpp fortran2.o

I changed the name from testing_... to try to trick the scripts not to go
through these files but now nothing works - even make clean.

To be done:
1) fix the scripts
2) figure out in what file to put 
   subroutine cublasAlloc
   subroutine cudaMallocHost
   ...
   and the module magma
3) The way is now cublasAlloc and cudaMallocHost and others
   (if we code them similarly) depend on the type. For example
   these handle float. How to make them general?
   e.g., pointers like
   real*8, pointer, dimension(:)::ptr
   would have to be different. I am not sure, are pointers in
   fortran some kind of integers. Can we change the definition with 
   something else
4) Start writing the example.
   I am going to say that we do it in the following way

!--- use the magma module
   use magma

!--- declare memory the ususal fortran way
   integer, allocatable :: ipiv(:)  

!--- declare GPU pointers and pinned memory pointers (as needed ...)
   real*8 pointer :: h_A(:), d_A(:)

!--- Allocate pinned memory (as needed ...)
   call cublasMallocHost(h_A, LDA*N*sizeof_real)

!--- Allocate GPU memory (as needed ...)
   call cublasAlloc(LDA*N, sizeof_real, d_A)

!--- Allocate on the CPU
   allocate(ipiv(min(M,N)))

 ...

!--- Call magma
   call magma_sgetrf(M, N, h_A, lda, ipiv, info)

 ...

r172 | tomov | 2010-05-28 18:27:47 -0400 (Fri, 28 May 2010) | 5 lines
Changed paths:
   M /trunk/src/sgeqrf_gpu-v2.cpp
   M /trunk/src/sgeqrf_gpu-v3.cpp
   M /trunk/testing/testing_sgeqrf_gpu.cpp
   M /trunk/testing/testing_sgeqrs_gpu.cpp

Added that LDA in the GPU-interface QR factorization (versions 2 and 3) 
must be divisible by 16 in order to benefit from coalescent memory accesses. 
Now, in testing, we make sure that the matrix is "padded" so that the LDA 
is divisible by 32. This is done in the least-squares solver as well.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
r171 | tomov | 2010-05-28 18:15:40 -0400 (Fri, 28 May 2010) | 5 lines

   M /trunk/testing/testing_sgeqrf_gpu.cpp

Added that LDA in the GPU-interface QR factorization must be divisible 
by 16 in order to benefit from coalescent memory accesses. Now, in testing, 
we make sure that the matrix is "padded" so that the LDA is divisible by 32.

Added that LDA in the GPU-interface Cholesky factorization must be divisible 
by 16 in order to benefit from coalescent memory accesses. Now, in testing, 
we make sure that the matrix is "padded" so that the LDA is divisible by 32.

r164 | tomov | 2010-05-26 14:22:45 -0400 (Wed, 26 May 2010) | 6 lines
Changed paths:

   M /trunk/src/spotrf-v2.cpp
   A /trunk/src/spotrf-v3.cpp
   M /trunk/src/spotrf.cpp
   M /trunk/testing/testing_spotrf.cpp

Small descriptions added. The old v2 is now v3.
v2 will be CPU interface routines that do not require the user to give
GPU memory. The memory required is allocated locally. Padded memory is
allocated to make sure lda is divisible by 32. The same would be added for 
the other precisions.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
r156 | du | 2010-04-19 22:55:37 -0400 (Mon, 19 Apr 2010) | 13 lines
Changed paths:
   M /trunk/magmablas/dtrsm.cu
   M /trunk/magmablas/strsm.cu
   M /trunk/testing/testing_dtrsm.cpp
   M /trunk/testing/testing_strsm.cpp

variable blocksize strsm and dtrsm

(1) removed hidden bugs caused by in-place sgemm/dgemm by using internal buffer, the copying of b might slow down the code a bit

(2) block size varialbe from 16 to 32, 64, 128,.... For smaller problem (small M in side=L case, for example),
	smaller block size like 64 would be better, while the opposite holds for bigger problem, say 128 or 256, rarely higher

(3) removed dependency to gemv32

(4) now might be a few Gflop/s slowdown for some solver in small size, automatic NB picking or autotuning will be apply soon

(1) Fixed the bug in sgemv32_kernel(similar fix in dgemv32_kernel). When M<BLOCK_SIZE, these two kernels should only compute M columns of A rather than BLOCK_SIZE cokumns(=32), otherwise gibberish data would tamper the result
(2) removed obsolete strsm.cu

r150 | du | 2010-01-22 02:43:44 -0500 (Fri, 22 Jan 2010) | 8 lines
Changed paths:
   M /trunk/magmablas/magma_strsm.cu

update to the inverse kernel

(1) fixed the bug about small random number on the diagonalsi (quite ghosty to track down to)
(2) split the inversing kernel into uplo=L and U cases
(3) removed branch divergence in the strmv part of the inverse kernel
(4) might have issues when trans=T. this is due to the fact that cublasSgemm doesn't work well with in-place case when its own trans=T.
